title: Rafoo Chakkar
text:
Rafoo Chakkar () is a <a href="Bollywood%20films%20of%201975">1975</a> Indian <a href="Hindi">Hindi</a>-language <a href="comedy%20film">comedy film</a> produced by Nadiadwala and directed by <a href="Narender%20Bedi">Narender Bedi</a>. The film was adapted from the 1959 American film "<a href="Some%20Like%20It%20Hot">Some Like It Hot</a>".
The film stars <a href="Rishi%20Kapoor">Rishi Kapoor</a> and <a href="Neetu%20Singh">Neetu Singh</a>, who were at the height of their popularity as an on-screen couple at the time of this film's release. Other actors include <a href="Kanwarjit%20Paintal">Paintal</a>, <a href="Bindu%20%28actress%29">Bindu</a> and <a href="Madan%20Puri">Madan Puri</a>, along with <a href="Rajindernath">Rajindernath</a>, <a href="Asrani">Asrani</a> and <a href="Bhagwan%20Dada">Bhagwan</a>. The music was composed by <a href="Kalyanji%20Anandji">Kalyanji Anandji</a>.
In the eponymous Feluda novel Joy Baba Felunath, Feluda shares his plan of watching this movie on the ninth day (Nobomi) of Durgapuja.
Plot.
The plot follows the general outline of "<a href="Some%20Like%20it%20Hot">Some Like it Hot</a>". Two out-of-work musicians (Rishi Kapoor and Paintal) witness a murder and are spotted by the villains. In order to save themselves, they decide to disguise themselves as girls and hop on to a train to Kashmir with other girls in a singing band, where they met Neetu Singh, Bindoo and Asrani. The plot twists when band manager <a href="Rajindernath">Rajindernath</a> falls in love with the 'girl' Paintal, and Rishi Kapoor tries to impress Neetu Singh by pretending to be an oil tycoon named Esso [A popular oil marketing firm). At the end of the movie, the male musicians' real identities are revealed. However, the romantic pairs remain intact by the end credits, including Rajindernath and Paintal. The movie ends with the same line as "Some Like it Hot": "Nobody's perfect!"
